awd_titl_txt: CAREER:   Building an informative machine learning model of plant gene regulatory control
awd_abstract_narration:
Despite the enormous potential of plant research for transformative advances in sustainable food and energy production, environmentally responsible materials biosynthesis, and safe effective medicines, a basic understanding of how plant genes are 'turned on' or 'turned off' in order to produce these useful products remains a primary scientific bottleneck. In order to understand how these genetic pathways function, one must identify and understand the patterns of DNA elements that ultimately control these genes. To address this fundamental scientific challenge in biological informatics, this project will use pattern recognition techniques in order to develop a detailed understanding of the way in which plant genes are controlled by DNA-encoded information. In order to do this, we will develop specific computational techniques for building and interpreting pattern recognition models. The most important aspect of this research is creating algorithms with the ability to recognize when a number of different DNA element patterns provide biologically relevant solutions for gene control. The algorithms, models, and biological outcomes developed by this project will be made available to the scientific community, including the plant science community. The underlying computational methods are expected to be applicable in many other fields of science and engineering. Teaching and training modules developed by this project will include outreach to our underserved communities of rural Oregon, including hands-on science experiences for high school students, as well as teacher training. The modules will draw special attention to the need for computationally trained researchers in the plant sciences, and to the need for a dramatically increased understanding of plant gene regulatory networks as a foundation for new drug discovery, agricultural, and materials biosynthesis challenges. 

The combinatorial control of gene expression by Transcription Factors (TFs) is one of the most fundamental regulatory mechanisms across the eukaryotic tree of life, from plants to humans. The DNA region surrounding the start of a gene, called the promoter region, contains short regulatory sequence elements known as Transcription Factor Binding Sites (TFBSs). In plants, despite the many exciting potential advances that hinge on a detailed understanding of plant gene regulation, relatively little is known about the specific TFBS patterns that lead to gene expression. This project uses and extends a machine learning model developed by the Megraw lab that is able to predict the presence of Transcription Start Sites (TSSs) with high accuracy and resolution. A primary advantage of this model is that it suggests specific sets of TFBS:promoter interactions which have the potential to 'turn on' a particular gene. This model makes novel use of currently available high-throughput TSS data to examine the global structure of promoters in the model plant Arabidopsis, and in preliminary research suggests striking unanticipated differences between plant and animal DNA regulatory codes. The goal of this project is to rigorously test and expand this promising new computational approach for dissecting which TFBS sets are optimal predictors of gene up-regulation in a biological sample. The relative simplicity of the Arabidopsis genome makes this challenge tractable, yet capable of providing transformative insight into gene regulation in a multicellular organism. The results of this project can be found at http://megraw.cgrb.oregonstate.edu/projects/PlantReg

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Developing a fundamental understanding of how plant genes are "turned on" or "turned off" at specific times and in specific tissues is key to tapping plants' enormous potential to address many of today's societal challenges.  In particular, understanding how the DNA sequence elements that control when and where genes 'express' their encoded proteins is needed to drive societal advances in safe sustainable production of food, energy, materials, and medicines.  The central research area of this award focused on developing algorithms with the ability to recognize when different DNA element patterns provide biologically relevant solutions for plant gene control.  The main study of this project successfully identified patterns of DNA 'promoter' elements that lead to tissue-specific gene expression through a machine learning modeling process.

Gene promoters are the important DNA-element containing regions on the genome that surround the start of each gene.  As part of our project we constructed a unique dataset that helps quantitatively identify the informative components of gene promoters that well-predict a gene's tissue of expression.  By taking advantage of the high quality annotation and extensive genomic resources in the model plant Arabidopsis thaliana, we were able to directly query the pattern of differences in the promoter sequences of genes that expressed highly only in root tissue vs highly only in shoot/leaf tissue of the same healthy plants.  As part of our modeling process, we were also able to incorporate 'chromatin' data, a type of data that indicates whether DNA segments of gene promoters are "open" and accessible to binding by protein complexes that help upregulate the gene, or "closed"  and 'bound-up' by proteins not related to gene regulation.

Our observations from the machine learning model analysis of this dataset challenged our previous assumptions that distal or "far away" chromatin-accessible TF binding site locations would be highly predictive of the tissue of expression for most promoters.  In fact, our findings strongly suggest that for the vast majority of cases, it is the pattern of DNA elements relatively nearby to the genes, regardless of chromatin state, that best explains the tissue of expression.  To the best of our knowledge this is the first study to directly test hypotheses about the types and location of genomic data that well-predicts a gene's tissue of expression.

While the modeling approach we used in this project is readily applicable to other organisms, the dataset that we gathered specifically for this purpose was enabled by using plant tissues, where it was possible to obtain tissues from different organs of the same healthy individuals using a pool of thousands of samples.  The framework developed in the project systematically identifies the locations of important DNA control elements for predicting tissue of expression, aiding foundations for understanding tissue-specific promoter design principles.  The algorithms, models, and biological outcomes developed by this project have been made available to the scientific community in publication, and also made available to the public by ensuring that all manuscripts and associated software products are freely available online through the NSF par.nsf.gov Public Access Repository system and the bioRxiv.org preprint server.

This project provided extensive training opportunities for undergraduate students, postbac students, and graduate students to learn how to apply computational pattern recognition techniques including machine learning to solve challenging problems in molecular biology.  Students from both biology and data science oriented backgrounds developed an understanding of molecular techniques used to produce the high quality large 'genome-scale' datasets necessary to support these machine learning based analyses.

Students at all levels helped develop training modules for outreach to our underserved communities of rural Oregon, including thought-provoking hands-on laboratory science experiences for high school students, teachers, and mentors.  These modules drew special special attention to the exciting promise of plant genomics research as an important foundation for meeting many of today's societal needs.  In the early years of this award, we offered these activities both in-person and online during Covid to the central Oregon community surrounding the Cascades campus of Oregon State University (OSU) in Bend.  During the post-Covid period of the award, we partnered with the Youth+ program to offer these modules to a cohort of high school students and their mentors from four rural counties in southwest Oregon.

We presented our post-Covid outreach offering each summer in a multi-day STEM Camp on OSU's main campus in Corvallis entitled "Plants and Medicine".  This camp offered laboratory activities featuring the ability of plant compounds to deactivate enzymes that can play a negative role in human health (e.g. bee venom enzymes), as a centerpiece for engaging students' interest in plant genome biology and bioinformatics.  Students were especially surprised by the connection between plants, including agricultural crops such as those grown in their own home regions, molecular biology, and plant-derived medical compounds including anti-microbials and clinically used cancer drugs.
